courseTitle: Kinematics: Finding Acceleration Due to Gravity

pageData.titleName2: Kinematics: Finding Acceleration Due to Gravity

pageData.text: The purpose of this experiment is to determine the acceleration due to gravity using an inclined plane. When you’re on or near the surface of the Earth, the pull of the acceleration due to gravity is constant. Acceleration is a vector, meaning it has a direction and a magnitude. The acceleration, g, acts straight down toward the center of the Earth, and the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity is g = 9.80 m/s2.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Kinematics: Finding Acceleration Due to Gravity

pageData.desc: Overview Video

text: Investigate how the displacement of an object rolling down an inclined plane is related to the elapsed time.
Determine the acceleration of an object rolling down an inclined plane through an analysis of displacement and time data.
Determine the acceleration due to Earth’s gravity, g, by interpreting the acceleration an object rolling down an inclined plane as a component of g.
Compare the experimental value of g with the accepted value of g = 9.80 m/s2.

pageData.text: Did you know that every time you sneeze, you essentially launch thousands of projectiles out of your nose? While very small droplets end up forming aerosols and are suspended in the air for long periods of time, larger droplets containing mucus act as projectiles being launched by force of sneeze and obey the laws of projectile motion. These droplets can contain pathogens, such as COVID virus particles. During the COVID-19 pandemic, scientists sought to model sneezing to figure out how to prevent transmission of the virus by looking at how droplets were launched out of the nose1. The scientists looked at how far the force of sneezing could launch projectiles of different sized particles and what factors might affect how the droplets move through the air. This research and similar studies helped scientists determine which mitigation strategies to implement to help limit the spread of the virus, such as social distancing, wearing face masks, and which types of gatherings were high risk.

1Cheng, C. H., Chow, C. L., & Chow, W. K. (2020). Trajectories of large respiratory droplets in indoor environment: A simplified approach. Building and environment, 183, 107196.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.buildenv.2020.107196

pageData.desc: A man sneezing, causing many large droplets to spray from his mouth and nose.
pageData.altText: A man sneezing, causing many large droplets to spray from his mouth and nose.

pageData.text: Galileo Galilei (1564–1642) observed that objects experiencing uniformly accelerated motion produced a pattern between the time interval of their motion and the distance they traveled.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: hypotenuse of a right triangle marked with five points to show distance increasing faster than time to demonstrate acceleration due to gravity
pageData.altText: Figure 1: hypotenuse of a right triangle marked with five points to show distance increasing faster than time to demonstrate acceleration due to gravity

pageData.text: The spacing between locations shown in Figure 1 and the time intervals are charted in Table 1. Notice that distance increases much faster than time increases.

The change in position for the time intervals increases by odd integers. Also, the total distances traveled, or the net displacement for the objects moving in a straight line, increase from t = 0 and were proportional to t2.

Although Galileo’s time was not the present-day definition of a second (he reportedly used his pulse, a water clock, and a pendulum), he was the first to define the concept of uniformly accelerated motion using Δv/Δt equal to a constant. He could not measure an object’s directly, so to test his definition, he used an inclined plane on which bells were placed at increasing odd-integer intervals. The bells assisted with his timing by providing an auditory alert of a bronze ball arriving at each position on the ramp. The incline’s vast length (12 cubits, or roughly 5.5 meters) allowed him enough time to take accurate measurements.
From your study of , you learned the definition of motion terms and their relation-ships. is defined as the net displacement, s, divided by the time interval, Δt.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: v sub average equals begin fraction s over delta t end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 1: v sub average equals begin fraction s over delta t end fraction

pageData.text: The average velocity is the sum of the initial velocity, vi, and the final velocity, vf, divided by 2.

pageData.desc: Equation 2: v sub average equals begin fraction v sub f plus v sub i over 2 end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 2: v sub average equals begin fraction v sub f plus v sub i over 2 end fraction

pageData.text: For objects experiencing , the acceleration is defined as the rate of change in velocity. By definition, acceleration, a, is the derivative of velocity, v, with respect to time, t.
Reverse this definition and integrate acceleration to find velocity. This results in the velocity-time kinematic equation of motion. Assume a constant acceleration.

pageData.desc: Equation 3: a equals begin fraction d v over d t end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 3: a equals begin fraction d v over d t end fraction

pageData.text: Definition of acceleration: a = dv/dt Multiply by dt. dv = a dt Integrate both sides.

pageData.desc: integral sup v sub v sub 0 d v equals integral sup t sub 0 a d t
pageData.altText: integral sup v sub v sub 0 d v equals integral sup t sub 0 a d t

pageData.text: Evaluate the result at the limits. v - v0 = at Rearrange terms to get Equation 4.

pageData.desc: Equation 4: v equals v sub 0 plus a t
pageData.altText: Equation 4: v equals v sub 0 plus a t

pageData.text: By definition, velocity is the derivative of displacement, s, with respect to time. Reverse this operation, and integrate velocity to find displacement. The result is the displacement-time equation for constant acceleration.
Definition of velocity: v = ds/dt Multiply by dt. ds = v dt Substitute Equation 4 for v. ds = (v0 + at) Integrate both sides.

pageData.desc: integral sup s sub s sub 0 d s equals integral sup t sub 0 being paren v sub 0 plus a t end paren d t
pageData.altText: integral sup s sub s sub 0 d s equals integral sup t sub 0 being paren v sub 0 plus a t end paren d t

pageData.text: Evaluate the result at the limits. s - s0 = v0t + 1/ 2 at2
Rearrange terms to get Equation 5.

pageData.desc: Equation 5: s equals s sub 0 plus v sub 0 t plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction a t sup 2
pageData.altText: Equation 5: s equals s sub 0 plus v sub 0 t plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction a t sup 2

pageData.text: This equation verifies Galileo’s relationship of the spacing between ball locations and the time interval. Although Galileo did not change his ramp’s elevation, we understand that different angles of elevation will result in different values for Δt and a when using the same displacement (ramp length). Measuring the length of your incline, s, and the time it takes an object to roll down the incline, Δt, you can determine the experimental acceleration of your object rolling down your inclined plane using Equation 5 with the initial condition that the object starts from rest, v0 = 0.
In this investigation, you will model Galileo’s ramp and observe the behavior of uniformly accelerated motion using an inclined plane; a hard, smooth, and round ball; and a stopwatch.

The force of gravity on an object that moves along an inclined plane is a vector quantity with components parallel and perpendicular to the plane with an angle of incline theta, θ. The component perpendicular to the plane presses the object into the surface of the plane and is equal to mgcosθ. The component of the force of gravity (weight = mass times the acceleration of gravity = mg) that acts parallel or along the plane accelerates the object down the plane and is equal to mgsinθ. The inclined plane in Figure 2 shows the components of the force of gravity parallel and perpendicular to the incline for a cart rolling down the ramp.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: diagram of a cart rolling down the inclined plane of a right triangle’s hypotenuse with the components of the force of gravity parallel and perpendicular to the incline
pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram of a cart rolling down the inclined plane of a right triangle’s hypotenuse with the components of the force of gravity parallel and perpendicular to the incline

pageData.text: There are various ways to use geometry to show that the angle between the cart and the force of gravity is equal to the angle of the ramp (see Figure 3). The angle between the force of gravity (weight = mg) and the line perpendicular to the ramp must be complementary to the angle at the top of the ramp, which is 90o – θ. Two angles are complementary if they add up to 90 degrees.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: a right triangle, with angle BDE and interior angle ABC showing the angle between the cart and the force of gravity is equal to the angle of the ramp
pageData.altText: Figure 3: a right triangle, with angle BDE and interior angle ABC showing the angle between the cart and the force of gravity is equal to the angle of the ramp

pageData.text: In Figure 3, the angle of the ramp is given by the angle ABC. The angle at the top of the ramp is the complement of this because the angles of a triangle add up to 180 degrees, so the angle BDE = 90<sup>o</sup> – θ.
The angle BCA must be equal to the angle BDE because the triangles EBD and ABC are similar, so angle BCA = 90<sup>o</sup> – θ.
Finally, the angle BCA must be complementary to the angle ACF because they add up to 90 degrees.
Angle BCA + Angle ACF = 90<sup>o</sup>
Substitute into this relationship angle BCA = 90o – θ and solve for Angle ACF.
90<sup>o</sup> – θ + Angle ACF = 90<sup>o</sup>
Angle ACF = θ

To obtain the expressions for the components of the force of gravity parallel and perpendicular to the plane, use trigonometry to project the weight vector (mg) onto the lines perpendicular to and parallel to the ramp (as shown in ). The component perpendicular to the plane is equal to mgcosθ. The component of the force of gravity (weight = mg) that acts parallel or along the plane is equal to mgsinθ.
relationship, F = ma, can be used to determine the acceleration along the ramp:
ma = mgsinθ
Dividing both sides by m gives Equation 6.

pageData.desc: Equation 6: a equals g sine theta
pageData.altText: Equation 6: a equals g sine theta

pageData.text: This is the relationship you will use to determine the theoretical acceleration of your object rolling down your inclined plane. Equation 6 will hold for objects being accelerated by gravity down an inclined plane if there is no friction.

The relationship of Equation 6 is an approximation of the acceleration of an object rolling down an inclined plane. This approximation is used to keep the content of this lab within the scope of the material you have studied in your physics course. Later in your physics course, you will study <button class='glossary-text'>rotational motion</button> and learn about the rotational counterparts to <button class='glossary-text'>translational (linear) motion.</button> When an object rolls, it experiences an <button class='glossary-text'>angular acceleration</button> due to the rotation of the object. You can return to this experiment and examine your results in light of rotational motion and include angular acceleration in your calculation.

You will also study energy and the <button class='glossary-text'>conservation of mechanical energy.</button> This experiment can be examined using conservation of mechanical energy incorporating both <button class='glossary-text'>translational kinetic energy</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>rotational kinetic energy</button> to get the same result that is obtained when translational and rotational <button class='glossary-text'>kinematics</button> are applied. If you want to apply the rotational component to your experiment, locate the rotational motion chapters in your textbook for additional information or search online to find scientific articles about the acceleration of an object rolling down an incline.

pageData.question: Can an object have increasing speed while its net acceleration is decreasing?

options.text: Yes; an example is an object released from rest in the presence of air friction.
No; if acceleration is decreasing the object will be slowing down.
No; the definition of acceleration makes this impossible.
Yes; an example is an object falling in the absence of air friction.
Yes; net acceleration is always opposite the speed of an object.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: An object can have increasing speed while its net acceleration decreases.  If an object is falling in the presence of air friction, the force of gravity will be constant, but the force due to air friction will get greater the faster the ball falls, thus creating a net force (and net acceleration) that approaches 0.

pageData.question: When an object is released from rest and falls in the absence of friction, which of the following statements is true concerning its motion?

options.text: The acceleration of the falling object is constant.
The speed of the falling object is proportional to its mass.
The speed of the falling object is proportional to its weight.
The speed of the falling object is inversely proportional to its surface area.
The acceleration of the falling object increases over time.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The acceleration is due to the force of gravity, which is constant.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Newton’s Second Law states that the Net Force = (mass) x (acceleration).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Newton’s Second Law states that the Net Force = (mass) x (acceleration).

pageData.altText: A map of the procedual workflow for this investigation. To begin, set up the foam board as a ramp. Then, mark the release and the stopping points. In activity one, calculate the dimensions of the incline. Then, record and determine the time for the ball to roll down the ramp. When you have completed three trials, increase the angle of the ramp and repeat. When all of the angles have been tested, calculate the average experimental acceleration and experimental acceleration due to gravity. In the extension activity, you will access the online simulation. Next, you will adjust the projectile motion parameters. Then, you will fire the projectile. When you have completed seven trials, you will repeat the trials with added air resistance.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Tammy is holding a ruler between Winston’s hands.  If Tammy releases the ruler without warning, approximately how far will the ruler fall before Winston catches it?  Human reaction time is usually greater than 0.10 seconds.
An object is moving in a straight line with constant acceleration.  Initially it travels at 16 m/s. Three seconds later, it is travelling at 10 m/s. How far does the object travel during this time?
When an object is released from rest and falls in the absence of friction, which of the following is true concerning its motion?

options.text: Both its acceleration and velocity are constant.

assestmentData.question: Two objects of different mass are released simultaneously from the top of a 20-meter tower and fall to the ground.  If air resistance is negligible, which of the following best describes how the two objects will reach the ground?

options.text: Both objects hit the ground together.
The smaller mass hits the ground first.
The greater mass hits the ground first.
Neither object will hit the ground.
There is not enough information to know the outcome.

assestmentData.question: An object with a mass of 2.3 kg is released from rest and slides down an 8.5-degree incline where the acceleration due to gravity is 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>. Assuming there is no friction, what is the component of the object’s acceleration perpendicular to the incline?

An object with a mass of 2.3 kg is released from rest and slides down an 8.5-degree incline where the acceleration due to gravity is 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.  What is the component of the object’s acceleration parallel to the incline?

A golf ball and basketball are released from rest at the top of a 5.7-degree incline.  If there is no friction, which of the following statements is true about the rate of acceleration down the incline of each ball?

options.text: The balls each accelerate at 0.97 m/s<sup>2</sup>.
The balls each accelerate at 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.
The acceleration of the golf ball is greater than the acceleration of the basketball.
The acceleration of the basketball is greater than the acceleration of the golf ball.
There is not enough information to determine the acceleration.

assestmentData.question: An object with a mass of 2.3 kg is released from rest and slides down an 8.5-degree incline where the acceleration due to gravity is 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.  The object travels the length of the incline, which is 1.9 meters.  Assuming there is no friction, how long does it take the object to travel down the incline?

pageData.text: Create a work space. Read through the investigation.
Obtain the required materials.
Study the material in your textbook covering measurements and uncertainties or locate reliable resources online.
Study the material in your textbook covering measurements and uncertainties or locate reliable resources online.

Using the foamboard and the angle bar for support, create an incline of approximately 2 degrees by placing a book or other support under one end of your board. (An angle of 2 degrees with the horizontal would have a hypotenuse of 100 cm = 1.00 m and a height of 3.5 cm = 0.035 m.)

Attach a piece of tape to mark the top of the incline to indicate the place for releasing your steel ball and starting the time measurement. Place another piece of tape at the bottom of the incline to indicate the place for stopping the time measurement.
In Activity 1, you will time the rolling of a steel ball down a ramp at various angles. You will use the time and dimensions of the ramp to calculate the experimental acceleration due to gravity.

typeBefore.text: Note: All measurements need to be recorded in SI Units and contain the correct number of significant digits.

pageData.text: Measure the distance between the centers of the markers on the incline. This is the length of the incline (hypotenuse), the distance r shown on Figure 4. Measure the height of the incline (opposite side to the incline angle), the distance y on Figure 4. The distance y should be the height of the incline above the horizontal. Record these values in the Lab Notebook for Incline 1. (An angle of 2 degrees with an r = 100 cm = 1.00 m would have a y = 3.5 cm = 0.035 m.)

pageData.desc: Figure 4: right triangle labeled with the hypotenuse as r, the opposite side as x, and the adjacent side as y
pageData.altText: Figure 4: right triangle labeled with the hypotenuse as r, the opposite side as x, and the adjacent side as y

pageData.text: Calculate the angle of the incline, and record the value in the Lab Notebook for Incline 1 θ = sin-1 (length of opposite side, y/length of hypotenuse, r) = sin-1 (y/r)

Place the steel ball at the marker at the top of the incline. Start your video stopwatch, then release the ball from rest. Stop the video stopwatch after the ball has passed the marker at the bottom of the incline.

pageData.text: Using the playback of your videos, determine the time it takes the steel ball to move between the markers at the top and bottom of your incline. Record these times in Data Table 1.
Increase the angle of your incline to approximately 4 degrees by placing another book or other support under one end of your board.
Measure the height of your second incline above the horizontal. The length of the incline (hypotenuse) should remain constant. Record these values in the Lab Notebook for Incline 2.

Place the steel ball at the marker at the top of the incline. Start your video stopwatch, then release the ball from rest. Stop the video stopwatch after the ball has passed the marker at the bottom of the incline.

Calculate the experimental acceleration for each trial using the relationship in Record your values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3 as experimental acceleration, a.
Calculate the average experimental acceleration, a, for each incline. Record these values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3.
Calculate the experimental acceleration due to gravity, g, using the average experimental acceleration, a. Record these values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3.
Share one of your videos for each angle in the Lab Notebook.

In the Extension Activity, you will use an online simulation to adjust projectile parameters and observe the resulting flight of the projectile without air resistance.  You will then repeat the trials with air resistance and how this changes the projectile’s flight.

Experiment with the simulation. Move the canon up and down and side to side. Move it to the left side of the screen, and raise it up to a height of 10 m above the center of the road. Use the measuring tape in the simulation to accurately position the canon.
For the shell type, select any of the types listed. Set the angle to zero degrees and the initial velocity to 15 m/s. (Use the magnifying glass in the upper left to zoom out.)

Fire the projectile, and measure the horizontal displacement from the cannon to the location where the projectile lands on the road. Record the type of projectile, the distance it traveled, and the projectile’s mass in Data Table E1.
Take a screenshot to be included in the Lab Notebook.

pageData.text: Repeat the experiment for a total of seven different projectile types. Record the type of projectile, the distance it traveled, and the projectile’s mass in Data Table E1.

Check the box for air resistance. Then using the same setup as Step 5, repeat Steps 6 through 8 using the same projectiles. Record the type of projectile, the distance it traveled, the time, and the projectile’s mass in Data Table E2.
Return the materials to the equipment kit, and clean the area.

text: Using the experimental acceleration due to gravity values from each data table, determine the standard deviation, σ, mean, μ, variance, σ2 and the 95% margin of error (confidence level). Record your calculations for upload in Question 3.

Using the 95% margin of error (confidence level) values for the experimental acceleration due to gravity, determine the % error. Record your calculations for upload in Question 3. % error = (| A–E |/A)x
Upload a photo of your error analysis calculations.

pageData.text: Click on the browse button to upload the file

text: Theoretically, which incline angle should provide a more accurate result and why?
Based on your data, which incline angle provided a more accurate result?  Is this in agreement with the theoretical angle?  If not, why?
Why do you need an inclined plane to measure the effects due to gravity?
How fast do you expect a ball released from rest to be moving at the end of a 1-meter inclined plane at a 45-degree angle?
If the inclined plane were truly frictionless, how should the ball’s acceleration depend on its mass?
Describe at least two possible sources of error in your experiment.  Could you reduce or eliminate these errors?  If so, explain how.

text: Compare the distance you calculated to the distance you recorded using the simulation.  Discuss why they are the same or different and why.
Discuss whether or not some projectiles traveled further than others without air resistance.
Discuss whether or not some projectiles traveled further than others with air resistance.
With air resistance, describe what seemed to have the most effect on the distance travelled: size, mass, or some other factor(s)?

pageData.content: Table 1. Figure 1 change in position over time
pageData.title: Table 1.

pageData.content: Equation 1. Average velocity in terms of displacement
pageData.altText: Equation 1: v sub average equals begin fraction s over delta t end fraction

pageData.content: Equation 2. Average velocity in terms of final and initial velocity
pageData.altText: Equation 2: v sub average equals begin fraction v sub f plus v sub i over 2 end fraction
Equation 3: a equals begin fraction d v over d t end fraction
Equation 4: v equals v sub 0 plus a t
Equation 5: s equals s sub 0 plus v sub 0 t plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction a t sup 2

pageData.content: Figure 2. Forces on an inclined plane
pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram of a cart rolling down the inclined plane of a right triangle’s hypotenuse with the components of the force of gravity parallel and perpendicular to the incline

pageData.content: Figure 3. Determining angle at the top of the ramp
pageData.altText: Figure 3: a right triangle, with angle BDE and interior angle ABC showing the angle between the cart and the force of gravity is equal to the angle of the ramp

pageData.content: Equation 6. Acceleration on an inclined plane due to gravity
pageData.altText: Equation 6: a equals g sine theta

A map of the procedual workflow for this investigation. To begin, set up the foam board as a ramp. Then, mark the release and the stopping points. In activity one, calculate the dimensions of the incline. Then, record and determine the time for the ball to roll down the ramp. When you have completed three trials, increase the angle of the ramp and repeat. When all of the angles have been tested, calculate the average experimental acceleration and experimental acceleration due to gravity. In the extension activity, you will access the online simulation. Next, you will adjust the projectile motion parameters. Then, you will fire the projectile. When you have completed seven trials, you will repeat the trials with added air resistance.
Figure 4: right triangle labeled with the hypotenuse as r, the opposite side as x, and the adjacent side as y

data.title: Angular acceleration
data.content: The rate of change in angular velocity with respect to time

data.title: Average velocity
data.content: The ratio of displacement from point A to point B to the time elapsed

data.title: Conservation of mechanical energy
data.content: The prinicple that energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only transform from one type to another

data.title: Instantaneous velocity
data.content: The velocity of an object at a specific point in time

data.title: Kinematics
data.content: A specific branch of mechanics that describes the motion of objects without reference to the forces causing the motion

data.title: Newton's second law
data.content: States that the net force is equal to mass times acceleration

data.title: Rotational kinetic energy
data.content: The energy possessed by an object by virtue of its rotational motion

data.title: Rotational motion
data.content: Motion that is rotates around an access

data.title: Translational kinetic energy
data.content: The energy possessed by an object by virtue of its translational motion

data.title: Translational motion
data.content: Motion in one dimension; also called linear motion

data.title: Uniform acceleration
data.content: The change in angular velocity with respect to time
